newsitem.title: THAILAND: Bank of Thailand urges market to ignore baht rumours.
newsitem.headline: Bank of Thailand urges market to ignore baht rumours.

text.p: The Bank of Thailand urged investors to ignore rumours in the market of a possible devaluation of the baht, and repeated its stance that it would not change the currency exchange mechanism.

"The central bank would like to ask the private sector to have confidence in the government policy and not to listen to the rumours," the bank said in a statement received on Thursday. "To listen to the rumours would be supporting speculators who like to destroy confidence and the stability of the country."
"The central bank wishes to stress that there would be no devaluation or changes in the currency exchange mechanism which were mentioned by rumors."

"(On Wednesday) there was fierce speculation on the baht in the overseas market," the statement said. "At present the situation has eased to a certain degree. The Bank of Thailand has closely followed and solved the problem in both the value of the baht and the liquidity of the money market system."
On Wednesday the central bank and the Monetary Authority of Singapore jointly intervened in the foreign exchange market to defend the baht.
The Thai central bank said the intervention was meant to protect against speculation on the currency and to preserve the stability of the Thai and regional money markets.
The Thai baht was firmer in early dealings on Thursday, with the bid/ask around 25.870/25.900 compared with around 26.330/26.430 in late dealings on Wednesday.
